title: Compared to the size of the sun, in what range of sizes are nearly all stars found? - Quora

response.answer_text: Smaller than our Sun. One often reads that our Sun is an ‘average star…actually it isn’t. It’s in the largest 10% even though it is much smaller than some larger types. Think of the Sun as a Squirrel….a lot bigger than a mouse. A squirrel is much smaller than an elephant but there are many more times mice than elephants and other larger mammals. At one time we thought our Sun average but this was only because we were unaware of the large number of blue dwarfs, etc ‘out there’.

Red dwarf stars comprise the majority of the stars in our Milky Way Galaxy. These are a coolIsh red stars perhaps one tenth the Suns mass. While the Sun is a G-type main-sequence star (G2V type) yellow star that make up perhaps a tenth of the stars in the Galaxy. That's roughly twenty billion stars.

You need to look at the ‘main sequence’ and bigger & smaller ‘outliers’ in a picture. Try this; Main Sequence - Universe Today Around 90 percent of stars are main sequence We believe they fuse hydrogen atoms forming core helium atoms. They range from about a tenth of a solar mass to up to 200 solar masses. Other types can have even greater variance! Though the sun is in the smaller side of the ‘type’ size range it’s on the larger side of the numbers game, as there are more smaller ones. Stars have a life, then when dying or dead it seems they’re accreted to the growing AGN for re-ionization. Ours is estimated at some 5–6Bn yrs old and is due for it’s ‘mid life’ crisis any time!
Stars vary in size from 0.08 solar masses up to 250–300 solar masses. About 80% of stars have lower masses than the Sun
